segments.text: I want to know when the lights come on in New York City immediately.
Of course, here I'm sitting here in the Pentagon, you know.
How are we going to find that out?
Not that I got an idea.
Governor's Island then was still an Army post.
Now I think the Coast Guard got it.
So I called them up on the phone.
And a sergeant.
answered the telephone.
He was a duty sergeant, I guess, because obviously this is a night when all everything's black.
I said, Sergeant, I have a problem.
He said, yes, sir, what it is?
I said, if I can help you.
I said, I have to know immediately when the lights come on in New York City.
Can you help me?
He said, well, certainly.
I said, what are you going to do?
He said, I'm going to get a private and post him out there and watch.
And just as soon as Lower Manhattan, those lights come on, I'm going to let you know.
I said, thank you, Sergeant.
Really appreciate that.
So that solved that problem.
Of course, that didn't bring the lights on.
And I notified the Navy.
Of course, when you notify the Navy or the Army and say, yes, they want to know who's going to pay for this, because they had to move some of the ships because of the dockside.
Of course, some of the crews are gone.
It takes time to get them underway.
But they said, sure, that they would do that.
Fortunately, all of our tactical airfields have auxiliary.
So they had no problems on their own.

runways as far as some thought for a while this might be a preliminary to some sort of an attack because it's so widespread and all the experts couldn't figure it out you know but that this is impossible so we have a grid system this goes out it's just rerouted any way you can have a massive blackout like this plus the fact is that why you have it it was two or three different places which i called it circuit breakers that would occur what would take them all out

course you know the solution finally was a massive surge reverse surge they've just overloaded everything that went up now i really don't know why or how what caused that tremendous reverse surge that knocked out on but it took them weeks to finally decide at least to announce that did they did they use the navy that way yep navy moved up and uh they were able to start
The auxiliary generator, of course, that was just a small thing.
It didn't help the city very much.
The Army assisted with a generator, enabled Cronkite to come on and report by candlelight.
At least he had power for his broadcast.
But it was calls coming from
Many places.
And they'd come in because this was getting to be late at night.
What are you doing?
Have the lights been turned on.
What do you hear?
And the lights and power didn't come on until the next day.
I think it was in the afternoon.
But people were in a frantic, you know, they were on elevators to stop, you know, blackout.
And you had people there.
And how you get them out, and they pounded.
And the birth rate went up, you know, after that.
A lot of people had nothing else to do.
Now, another more hairy type of experience, these are what you have, and you have to stay right with it, of course.
You have people that expect you to have more information than anybody.
Sure.
And that's your job to get it.
But one night, we thought we had a quiet night.
And in the...
We have a conference room also.
We've got a big display board up here that shows the dew line across the North.
And only once we got alert, both from the Colorado Springs American Command that was showing up, there's an unidentified object coming towards the United States.
and just be happy the heading is coming from the USSR.
And now you're really under the gun.
At what point do you push the panic button?
And what you do is an SOP, of course you notify the Joint Chiefs of Staff and the President, because they say it's got to be made, what are we going to do about that?
Are we going to shoot it down, or what is it?
And they finally figured out that monitoring this thing and tracking it
It was too fast to be an aircraft.
It must be a missile.
And now it's getting pretty close to the dew line up there.
They've been monitoring it out in the distance.
And so I was talking to Colorado Springs.
I said, at what point do you think that I should alert the Joint Chiefs of Staff and the president?
And he said, well, it's getting pretty close.
Because the way we figured it, it's
It's minutes, of course, it's still quite a few minutes from the United States, but you've got to react to a ship scrambling aircraft.
Well, they did scramble aircraft.
So did you notify the Joint Chiefs then?
No, I hadn't done it yet, Steve.
But NORAD scrambled the aircraft?
Yeah.
Without notifying the Joint Chiefs?
Well, they can do that routinely.
But they weren't going to attack it.
This is just getting airborne into position.
Of course, they'd have a hell of a time attacking a missile.
Sure.
So...
Once again, I was lucky, because my decision to delay it was correct.
Because then I got a hurried call back and said, hold everything, because we've just found out what our problem is.
It was a computer that was miscalibrated properly or something.
Anyway, it was misreading something that wasn't there, I said.
But it was really coming just as if it was headed for the United States.
So you get situations like that, and you finally
Find out if it's OK.
It's such a sense of relief.
It's like somebody taking a great load off.
Another situation, I'll just tell one more, and then I'll move along to something else.
I had a call one night.
And the reason why things happen at night, when it's nighttime, of course, in Washington, it's daytime in Vietnam and a lot of other places in the world.
So it can be very active in the MCC at night.
and slow going in the daytime.
Plus the fact you got everybody to help you in the daytime.
You know, the chairman of the joint, everybody's there.
You don't have all that responsibility.
You just let them call in.
And although you handle everything, you don't ever call anybody unless it's really a need to.
So I had that call.
They said that Cuba has just captured
one of our ships and that came out of I guess Key West.
How do you know?
Says because we were monitoring and we listened to it and we had the Cubans said I have captured and the name the name of the ship.
So we immediately asked where is that ship?
Oh yes this is a scientific
I don't remember where it was from, MIT or some college or university, was assigned as a board doing some sort of underwater research.
And on that type of ship, they only come on the air as intervals because they don't have anybody to sit in the communication room 24 hours a day.
This is not a U.S. government ship, is it?
Yeah.
It was a U.S. government ship?
Yeah.
No, it was private.
It was a private research ship.
Yeah.
Okay.
Well, sometimes that's a cover for intelligence.
In this case, this was a legitimate research.
And so after hearing this, well, we've got to check it out, see.
So they scrambled some planes down in Florida.
And they flew over the ship and actually got dived down real close.
But later on, we found out this kind of frightened the crew aboard that because they couldn't figure out what the hell is everybody coming around here getting so close to.
It was off Cuba, near Cuba, but in international waters, like Cuban waters.
And there was some Cuban ships at a distance, but not right alongside this particular one.
Crap.
So then the question comes, what are we going to do?
Because it appears to be heading for the harbor.
Are we going to intercept it?
And that's the unit side, too.
You could really make a stupid mistake.
In this instance, there wasn't any service nearby.
So I was trying to figure out what we were going to do, what could be done, when
It just so happened that this ship came on the air.
I guess they came on the air because they were kind of disturbed that they were being attacked.
Not really attacked, but scared.
Going down.
In fact, they'd go down so low they could read the name on the side.
And they come on there.
And they said, well, we have had a report that you were captured by the Cubans.
Have you been captured?
They said, oh, no.
We haven't been bothered.
But we monitored it.
And it says, I have been captured.
I have captured this name.
Well, as it turned out, this just shows you how the lack of communication or improper communication.
What the Cubans said, or the translation was wrong.
When they said, I have captured, they mean with the eye.
I see.
And they were...
They were identifying the ship back to their headquarters that they were observing.
That shows you how you can get really all brewed up during the nighttime or something like that.
Well, that's enough of those.
Anyway, every day that was something pretty interesting.
You must have really been sort of on the firing line.
Well, I'm going to have to tell one more because this is one of the...
We had another bombing pause.
This is separate from the other.
We had several, you know, during the bombing pause.

We had a paper that said, it went out to the far east of Westmoreland's command, of which Admiral Stark and the think tank knew that the president had authorized that if you were being attacked, then you were authorized
to commence bombing without coming back and getting the president's permission.
Otherwise, do not bomb until authority is given from the president.
And this happened on a weekend when everybody's gone.
Admiral Stark called in personally, when I was on duty, and said that Westmoreland wants us to resume the bombing.
And Westmoreland didn't control the bombing.
Think back.
He just had the ground war.
And I'd like to have permission, says Admiral Stark, to commence bombing.
I said, sir, I can't give you an answer now, but I'll call you back in just a few minutes.
Well, General Wheeler, who was the chairman of the Joint Chiefs at that time, wasn't there.
The acting chief, chairman,
was the Air Force General, Grok.
I can't recall his name right now.
And he said, well, that's easy.
He says, you just tell Admiral Stark to commence bombing.
I said, well, don't you think we better refer this to at least the Secretary of Defense?
No.
But we have the piece of paper.
Tell him to go ahead.
I'll take full responsibility.
He really wasn't in a position to take full, even though he was active chief, but this was a little bit stronger medicine.
Well, now I'm on the spot.
Am I going to disregard a four-star general that really I'm working for in the MCC?
Well, Vance was always a good, steady pre-NC to all of us, and he was the deputy secretary of defense.
Sonny Vance, yeah.
So I called him up.
And of course, he was hard to get a hold of, because he was out guest somewhere.
And I had to run down several times as a guest in an office somewhere.
And that makes it difficult, because you can't talk classified.
Now you're next out again.
Because all of this is monitored.
Everything we said is taped.
It's taped for protection, both of the people that you're talking with, and also to be sure they're accurate.
Who said what?
I wanted it taped.
Terrible things can happen with mistakes like that.
So I called him up and I said, the acting chairman had given Admiral Stark the green light to commence bombing him.
And there was a long pause.
I said, hello, sir, are you still there?
He said, yes, I'm still there.
I said, is there anything you want me to do?
I just wanted to be sure you were informed.
He said, no, you don't do anything.
Take it from a collar.
I'll take it from here.
And I never heard any repercussions from that.
So apparently, I'm sure that was something.
So you didn't give Stark the green light?
Oh, no.
Or did you?
No, that's another thing.
After he told me that, after I talked to Vance,
We still had the responsibility.
And I told him what I was going to do.
I didn't recite this very accurately because that's what I was told to do.
And he paused a long time and said, oh, that's all right.
Thank you for calling.
I'll handle it from here.
So I called Admiral Stark back and told him that it was affirmative.
And then I got to thinking, what he needs is an order.
He ought to have that in writing.
So I called back the gentleman and I said, I think this ought to be in writing.
I relate orally of what you directed, but I think he ought to have a message.
Oh, no, he don't need a message.
And he said, all right, send one if you want to.
I said, who shall I have sign?
Your name?
Yeah, I'll sign it Monday.
So we sent off a message confirming.
I'll say it never was any repercussion, so I don't know what dance he probably called the president and told him.
We'll have to get off of that one.
Well, I wanted to know, there's a number of things at first I want to know about this.
this job in the Pentagon.
That sounds absolutely fascinating.
One is, during this time there was a tremendous increase in the technology that America was using in fighting the war in Vietnam in a space program.

Was technology, and you've already alluded to this when you talked about the communication possibilities, but was technology, were there examples of rapid increase in new technologies in the Pentagon at this time?
This new communication system had just been installed, so I don't know of any...
So during that year, it was installed just before I got there, so I...
I don't know of anything... And they were computerizing a lot of things, too.
Aside from...
This was a day-to-day hour, many for many, but...
A lot of the things that we had files of being placed on the computer.
But I don't know of any, as you say, any dramatic additions we had or changes due to the space program or the development of technology.
Now, why did you only stay on this job for one year and then you went to Chief Far Eastern Division?
Because it was a one-year tour of duty.
And you got reassigned.
Everybody, they figured it.
One year is all that also should be there.
And also for his own benefit, you would want him.
True.
Gosh, actually, you've done that a few months.
Now, the troops invaded the Dominican Republic in 1966.
Were you on the hotline there?
Yeah.
Not there because, I'm glad you mentioned that, because whenever there's a troubled spot, they don't expect,
The flag also on duty to handle that.
You immediately set up a task force.
Sure.
It's in an MC.
There are rooms for the task force.
And that task force handles it.
Even their communications come right in there.
So the Dominican Republic was handled.
And that task force is similar.
You've got CIA, State Department, Department of Defense.
They're in a room right next to you.
Yeah.
So they can get all the information they need as fast as possible.
That's right, from us and from our facility and also from them.
Of course, they had to use the same communication.
And that was very active.
Also in NMC, we produced every day a top secret, I won't call it a newspaper, but it's more of a pamphlet or a magazine type of thing.
And that was our response.
We had to go to press early enough to get it all, to confirm the accuracy before the people who were deceived arrived.
And that would be the Chairman, Joint Chiefs, Secretary of Defense, and people of that category.
And it had a box score, the number of strikes we made during the last 24-hour period.
the number of planes we lost, what assessment we had of the damage.
But usually you had it because the reconnaissance plane flew right after you took a picture, and the carrier, and from otherwise too.
And summer of the ground action, where it occurred, that's right.
Number of casualties, number of prisoners taken, if any.
Later on, that crazy body count was stupid.
The press forced that on them, you know.
But tell me about that body count.
Of course, a number of people have said that that's distorted, and even a number of generals have said that the body count was distorted.
What were your feelings on that?
Well, I'm sure it was distorted.
Why did you say it was stupid?
Because they never should have started it.
The media forced it on them.
I'm not blaming them for the poor body feelings, but
But they gave an estimate, like you normally do anywhere.
We estimate 15 or 20 or whatever.
So they put the pressure.
What do you mean, estimate?
Either you know or you don't know what you base your estimate on.
So they keep pressing them like that to where they'd have to actually, that's how they got the body counts.
How do you know?
Well, we sent somebody out and they counted the body.
But that's the worst thing here.
Who?
Who goes and counts the bodies?
You don't go up and count children, dogs, and all other bodies.
But that's kind of a callous way.
Of course, war is a terrible thing the way you look at it.
But when you start, it would be much better, I think, to just give an estimate.
And I'm saying that estimate is exaggerated.
It probably was, or is.
But that's a more...
civilized way, I think.
But you weren't directly involved in any of the planning or staging of the Dominican Republic situation.
No.
They set up a task force.
Oh, we did.
It was monitored.
And it was well underway when I came in there.
That was one of my first tasks force.
OK.
I'd like you just to give your opinion of some of the people that you worked with who were very important during this time as far as national affairs.
And one of the most controversial is Robert Mackinac.
Well, he's really a difficult one to... Once again, brilliant mind.
Yeah.
Brilliant.
And he thinks he's usually ahead of the people mentally.
And therefore, like, makes him impatient.
And he particularly, if somebody would ask him a question of what he just said, like, that was really, he'd be impatient with that because he'd say, well, didn't you hear what I just said?
Of course, what this person means, maybe I heard it, but I don't quite understand it.
But he didn't like people like that around him, you see.
And he surrounded himself with some brain.
When they talked about the whiz kids, he got some really sharp, bright young people.
Most of them are scientifically trained.
And many of them didn't understand the weapons of war or how you fight a war.
But they were good because with their system analysis,
They tried to fight or win the war by system analysis.
And of course, if you could ever do that, we really progressed.
That would be good where you don't even need people in the field.
For example, the development of the electronics defense.
We were going to put that in, and nobody could penetrate because of monitoring.
But all sorts of things happened for them.
It cost a lot of money.
That was the system analysis of whiz kids and developing those things.
But McNamara, he was a positive and he was friendly in his own cold way.
You know, you didn't expect him to be smiling like that.
But he could kind of look at you with his eyes kind of half closed and kind of nod at you.
You knew that.
Apparently, everything's not so bad.

He was impatient with generals, admirals, and probably so because when you spend, say, 25 or 30 years in the military, all different situations, different places, you seem to assess the situation based on your education, background, experience, and so forth.
If you've got a civilian that hasn't trod that long rocky path, he comes from over here.
And he sees it, and it's good to have him to look at it, because he may see a lot of fresh new things that could be done and will be done.
But this guy here seems to be, and I guess I'm being impatient, I guess I figure that these generals are kind of slow and they put the status quo and they haven't had a new idea in years.
They're all training to fight the last war and never can foresee or project to create the future.
So, and these young guys, they weren't handicapped by experience.
You know, they're willing to try anything.
Well, they wouldn't call it trial and error, but it would be a... And I never heard any of them say something was wrong.
If it didn't pan out, it was because something had been overlooked.
So I guess what I'm saying is they saw the world entirely different than we saw it.
But we knew we had to do the fighting.
And we were responsible.
Just like, look at that desert fiasco in Iran.
Everybody says the military becomes a joke, and they shouldn't be.
Aircraft maintenance is poor.
You know, everything.
Why can't we learn to do at least as well as Israel can do, see, with all of that?
So we get the responsibility for whatever goes wrong or something doesn't work.
That's the reason I'm talking about Korea.
Yet, people change things or alter them, and then at the last moment,
They'll change their mind and say, well, I was wrong.
Fulbright said that, you remember, about the Gulf of Tonkin.
He said, yes, I voted for it.
I led.
I was the president's spokesman on that.
But I was wrong, because I bring back 50,000 young men.
But McNamara had these real fine guys.
Was there a lot of jealousy between, or not jealousy, antagonism, I guess, hard feelings between McNamara and the Whiz Kids and the upper echelon military?
Not so much with McNamara, but he really had some youngsters that, for example, Halpern is one.
You may recognize his name.
He's the one who's had the most.
Martin Halpern.
Martin Halpern.
You ever meet him?
No, he's a historian.
The one who sued Kissinger.
It was Kissinger and everybody else.
Martin Halpern had just finished Harvard, Ph.D.
He came to the Pentagon Department of Defense as a, what do you call him, research analysis, you know, a fellow, a White House fellow.
Well, he wasn't a White House fellow.
I said, maybe I'll think of the word in a few minutes.
Of course, they come in for a year for experience, and they're really studying government functions.
He was so intrigued with it, he stayed on.
He came to the Pentagon with preconceived ideas on everything.
And he wouldn't listen.
I served on committees with him.
In the Far East Division, we had a committee
Bill Bundy was on.
Brzezinski, you know, the former.
Sure.
He was on that committee.
Halbert was on it.
I was on it.
I represented joint staff.
Halbert represented the Department of Defense.
And we addressed, this was the Far East Division, this joint.
Did you have a State Department official on that too?
Yeah, he chaired it.
Bundy chaired it.
Oh, okay.
Bunded State had the Far East.
That was his area.
CIA man on that, too?
Yeah.
And he was the one name I couldn't remember who later became the chief.
So we had Brzezinski.
DIA on that, too?
You know, I don't remember about DIA, but they must have been on that.
OK, but what about an offering then?
Well, there was a paper.
that had been approved by the president of which, on this particular committee, and this was for the Far East, they had similar committees to other parts of the world.
And in it, it said, it was perfectly written that the Joint Chiefs of Staff had a vote, and the Department of Defense had a vote.
Halperin said, the Joint Chiefs are subordinate to the Department of Defense, therefore,
You cannot vote differently than I do.
And I said, but the paper, here it is right here.
He says, I don't care.
Now, he had been misled because before we went, we always had a subject agenda, of course.
And we would develop position papers.
And we always, before that, would take them over to Halpert for his agreement.
And there was another young man also from New York.
He worked on the transition.
team I noticed here a while back.
He's a lawyer from New York.
Because we weren't coordinated, and of course it would be unusual for us to really disagree, but there was disagreement.
He said he don't have the vote.
Well, we disagreed, so we went ahead and voted, and Halbert said, I object.
Mr. Chairman, because the Joint Chiefs do not have a separate vote, and this is counter to our vote, and I represent the Department of Defense of McNamara.
And I thought I disagreed, and I quoted the paper.
Bundy ruled that, for the time being, since the paper said two votes, that he would rule in my favor.
So the record will show that defense positions one in power over the other.
Later on, they supported the paper.
They didn't have to change the paper.
They fired everybody.
So they purposely wanted the Joint Chiefs to have a vote in these committees to represent the uniformed military as opposed to the other.
There wasn't any world-shaking problem at all.
But it was just Halperin's attitude.
Is that what you're saying?
Yeah, and that was his attitude on a lot of other things.
Then we finally got...
It was just uncooperative, or was that his deal?
Hard-headed.
He thought, I guess he was an example of what Ted Walsh was telling about some Ivy League type.
I'd hate to be working for Halverson.
It would be impossible to get along with him.
But he didn't understand.
Never had any military training.
He'd never been a private or ever been a Boy Scout.
Well, finally, he left the Department of Defense, and everybody just cheered.
And why did he show up over?
in the White House working for Kissinger.
And he started doing the same thing over there.
Of course, I had left then.
I went down to Fort Monroe, so I didn't have any dealings with him after he left the department then.
And I wasn't surprised at all to find out that he would be involved.
And I wasn't surprised to find out he was going to carry this suit to the Supreme Court.
See, the settlement was a dollar, and now since they won in the Supreme Court, they want to raise it to several million dollars.
The old principle at the beginning, but now he wants to make his million.
There was another guy, and I can't recall his name, but he was a partner of Halpern, and he went over to the State Department.
He messed us up in the Defense Department.
He went over and did the same thing with Halpern in the White House.
I meant the White House, not the State Department.
Now, what about Brzezinski?
What was your opinion of him?
Oh, he's probably the, of all of the guys that I've met around two years, he's probably the most brilliant.
And everybody agrees with that, even with his.
But sometimes he thinks, he's got a creative mind.
He's always thinking ahead.
And he's way ahead, even McNamara, he's ahead of him on it.
Of course, he doesn't have the training, the scientific training that old McNamara had.
Brzezinski has an idea, a concept, and a solution on every single problem.
So when we meet as a committee, and we even met to devise a way to end the war in Vietnam,
Couldn't get together, of course, because everybody... We made a trip to Vietnam together.
We got briefed at all levels.
When was that?
Well, it was before Khe Sanh was attacked.
You remember that went on for quite some time.
LBJ promised the nation, he says, the Joint Chiefs assured me Khe Sanh will not fall, which it didn't.
But we went to Khe Sanh, went to all of them, all over Vietnam.
And the situation wasn't so bad then.
In fact, that was the light at the end of the tunnel.
Everybody was seeing things.
But Brzezinski, I just can't praise him enough.
Now, I've noticed this critique of his service in the Security Council was that brilliant mind,
Great concept, great vision.
But then he didn't have the ability to implement.
When you get right down there, this is great.
Now, how do we get there from here?
See, now we've got to do this and this other thing.
He lost interest at that level.
So you needed somebody else to come over that followed him and everything he did, and then come back and build a place, a building block, where he could finally get to the objective.
But you would really be impressed if you just sit down and hear that guy talk.
What about Bundy?
Bundy, too.
Bundy, by the way, was on the firing line Sunday, whatever.
He's head of the Foreign Affairs magazine.
Bill Bundy.
Yeah.
He's a quiet, tall individual and not impressive at all.
I mean, what he does, obviously, he wouldn't be editor of this foreign affairs magazine, but you'd have to be around him, and I wasn't around him that much.
He always seemed to be preoccupied.
He'd come to our meetings late because he chaired them, and he didn't seem to always make himself busy on very important issues.
I don't know.
Up to speed on
what had been done and where we were.
So he had a little guy, and I forgot his name.
He ended up later being ambassador to Korea that carried the ball for Bundy on the sport.
He knew all about everything.
But he was a feisty little guy.
And he was a hawk.
Bundy was a dove.
Of course, he's probably correct.
You're not necessarily a dove if you don't agree with what's doing.
Maybe a hawk on what you think is right.
Of course, you also said that you knew Cyrus Vance.
Yeah.
Would you describe him?
Very friendly, humble type of individual.
Humility.
He's interested to know what you think of your ideas, not like McNamara, who doesn't care your ideas.
You know, he's already solved the problem, and you're wasting my time.
Resentka, the same thing.
He's already got his ideas concept.
He too is way ahead.
But Vance is a, and I think he's been criticized in,
the Secretary of State for this.
He wasn't necessarily a fighter.
He seemed to be more of a team player.
He doesn't want to create a diversified views.
He'd like to pull them together.
He would even come into the MCC,
He'd almost always preface his remarks, he'd like to know this, but don't.
I hope it doesn't appear or something else.
You know, when Deputy Secretary of Defense comes in and says, I want this done, you know, you figure out how you're going to do it.
Sure.
That's what I mean by humility.
He certainly wasn't arrogant.
And I think the Secretary of State, the way he ran that,
But I was a little surprised and kind of proud of him when he resigned because of that raid in Iran.
So with this white appearance, they have a strong mind and principle.
Of course, he was very knowledgeable.
He had been Secretary of the Army.
He had been Deputy Secretary of Defense, which means that they carry a big load.
of coordinating and running it, particularly getting into the budgetary.
Then he got to be Secretary of State.
So he really knew his way around.
And he knew the military, certainly the Army.
But he was on top of the information.
He knew he was preparing.
And I like him.
I admire him.
I think he's a real fine gentleman.
It's a pity that we couldn't temper
somewhere between Haig and Vance would be a real good solid Secretary of State, you know, not too positive and too strong in strong-minded views or saying things that Haig does.
This is it, you know, just a declaration of a fact when maybe it should be a declaration of a study, ongoing study that we're looking at.
Did you happen to get to know Alexander Hague at this time?
No.
He wasn't in the White House then at all.
No, he was not.
He was still a low-ranking colonel somewhere around in the Army.
Well, he was in Vietnam, that's where he was.
Tell me what you did as Chief Far Eastern Division when you left the National Military Command Center for the next two years.
Yeah, when I talk about this committee with State, this is as a chief here.
The Chief of the Far East Division

He is in charge of all plans concerning the area, which, of course, is designated as Japan and Korea, the Philippines, Taiwan, Vietnam, Laos, Cambodia, Burma, Thailand, Indonesia, and the islands in the Pacific, which we're not custodian.
Territories.
Territory, yeah.
That was included and that came into active play because then they were still discussing, you know, what were they going, what's going to be the status.
Freedom would become a commonwealth.
And what was your
I mean, when you are chief, obviously you're not dealing with the command decisions in Vietnam, although that's in the Far East Division.
What exactly are you dealing with?
Policy planning?
You have a good point.
Since Vietnam and Laos and Cambodia was an active theater, this became operational planning.
So that was taken out of our shop.
Now, long-range planning
if we're talking about what will happen as a cessation of hostilities.
And that would come in our ear.
Thailand was in between, see?
That's supposed to be neutral.
So we have a lot of planning to do with Thailand, because they have a member of CETO.
That's all changed now.
And that would come under us.
When CETO had a meeting in Washington, for example,
my division was responsible for organizing and planning the meeting, which brings back to McNamara.
Mrs. McNamara, bless her soul, she recently ceased from cancer.
We had all this planned.
And so of all things, now this is like the detail I could expect Jimmy Carter to ask for.
She asked for the list.
of liquor, kinds of liquor, that we were going to serve.
Where?
At this reception.
Oh, at a reception.
The Cito Meats business bar and the social that followed it.
So we had listed Smirnoff Vodka and Cutty Sorts, Scotch.
She came back and she changed all of them.
Two-inch pegs that cut back some cutting saw to a cheaper stock and spurred off back to a cheaper vodka.
And all across the board.
And she really didn't have anything to do about it, except she did, of course, he had a responsibility for it.
She was just interested in keeping costs there.
I thought that was, to me, an interesting sideline of what Ms. McNamara was doing, her attention to detail.
Then I had a division, an organization, where
But people were organized by country.
In some cases, more than one country was divided up.
So any paper that comes to us, and it could be generated by the Army, Navy, Air Force, or Marines concerning our area, we would handle it and staff it through the Joint Chiefs.
And there's a regular way you may know it with different colors they call them.
And that indicates the stage that you're in when you start out.
you end up buff, you know, you work it.
When you finally get it to where everybody agrees it's ready to go to Joint Chiefs, then it is actually a green color.
And then when they agree to it, I've already forgotten what color it is, it's published in a different color.
So that's the short way to say, what's the status of this?
You say, well, it's still in the buff.
And then you have to arg it.
or be prepared to argue to the Joint Chiefs when they meet.
You have to answer all the questions about it.
Now they have, they're prepared because their staff has studied it and used and made notes, changes, or additions.
So sometimes it doesn't, it can take hours, sometimes days before it's ever done.
But much of the discussion, of course, there's many things narrowed down to budget.
in the Army Navy Air Force, sure, nobody would accept a change that would end up saying, well, you just gave up one squadron of aircraft, but this means two more ships going to multiple things.
How many men did you have under your command as chief?
I think about 20.
About 20, and they were probably all officers?
Yeah.
Oh, yeah, they were.
And they were all experts in certain fields, in certain countries?
They were all colonels or...
or captains of the Navy.
And what?
Do you remember what your plans were for future Vietnam?
No, not really, because the plan was to restore the stability of the government and have it operated out of Seoul.
I mean, out of Saigon.
Did you feel that in your job, anybody was listening to you?
Or was the Vietnamese word so important that they didn't worry about the future plans for the Philippines or for Japan or whatever?
Well, of course, the plans are... Actually, all the focus was on Vietnam to get there.
